head.supplied: Melbourne, ¶ 18 febr, 1888. ¶ Rob. Watson Esqr, ¶ Chief Engineer of the Railway Department. ¶ ¶ Of the wood-samples, sent by you, dear Mr Watson, ¶ the one marked N. 1 ¶ is from Eucalyptus goniocal...

div.p: 88/1175, unit 89, VPRS 425/P, Engineer-in-chief inward correspondence, VA 2876 Victorian Railways, Public Record Office of Victoria.
Chief Engineer of the Railway Department.

Of the wood-samples, sent by you, dear Mr Watson,
See Watson to M, 18 February 1888. the one marked N. 1
MS annotation in the margin: 'No 1 — 17 miles from Birregurra in the Lorne district. —' is from Eucalyptus goniocalyx, the species passed as "Spotted Gumtree" in Victoria. The timber of this tree is fairly durable underground, so that it can be chosen also for railway sleepers.

The sample marked N. IV
MS annotation in the margin: 'No 4 — Timber from which the Barrum River Coy are cutting Sleepers'. is from the genuine "Blue Gumtree," Eucalyptus Globulus, which — as you are aware —, has often been drawn into use for railway-sleeper; under ordinary circumstances it will last for that purpose a series of years; — but the Officers of your Departments must for many years have collected information locally on this universally used kind of timber, so that the results of their comparison may be ascertained also.
MS annotation in the margin: 'No 2 — Barrumunga 18 1/2 miles from Birregurra No 3 — Barrumunga 20 1/2 miles from Birregurra".
On 2 March 1888 name, wrote to Watson, in a letter headed 'Terang to Warrnambool Railway': 'We are in receipt of your memo. Re Blue gum forest informing us that the report of your Inspector is against it and that it is not the true blue gum. In reply we can only state, that the Timber experts we sent to examine the forest on our behalf, reported to us, that it was the same blue gum, that had been accepted by the Railway Department, from the Barrum River Saw Mill Co. of Apollo Bay and they still hold that opinion.' They went on to ask if they could substitute Box Red Gum, or Ironbark, for the Blue Gum as they had no other source in Victoria for obtaining the latter for sleepers (88/1585, unit 89, VPRS 425/P, PROV).
The two other samples, III & IV, are accompanied only by branches without buds, flowers and fruits; and altho' I have some idea what these two are, it will be more satisfactory to adjudicate on them professionally from complete material, more particularly so, as in all probability one (at least) of these sorts will have to be rejected for sleepers on railways.
